Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: Maternal reproductive trade-offs and the duration of exclusive breastfeeding in a natural fertility population

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
International health organizations recommend exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months of life to promote optimal infant growth and reduce risk of infectious illness. Globally, however, exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months is relatively rare - including in many less developed populations with high rates of infectious disease. For many mothers, the risks associated with complementary feeding before 6 months of age may not be apparent, or may be outweighed by competing time and energy demands. This study will examine differences in infant feeding patterns and associated outcomes in an economically marginalized population, the Tsimane of Bolivia.

This research by doctoral student Melanie Martin (University of California, Santa Barbara), under the supervision of Dr. Michael Gurven, tests the hypothesis that maternal work and childcare demands reduce the length of exclusive breastfeeding. Furthermore, because nursing mothers rapidly lose weight and do not menstruate, Tsimane mothers may introduce complementary foods before 6 months of age to minimize the caloric losses of nursing. This offset may enable postpartum weight maintenance and earlier resumption of menstruation. Tsimane women do not have access to contraceptives; early complementary feeding may therefore contribute to Tsimane mothers' high fertility rates (average 9 children).

The researchers will survey Tsimane mothers to determine if the length of exclusive breastfeeding varies with infant condition, maternal age and condition, and maternal work and childcare demands. Researchers will also prospectively collect dietary, behavioral and biological data from Tsimane mothers and infants to examine how complementary feeding patterns affect maternal energy, menstrual status, infant growth and incidence of illness. The study will examine how local beliefs and Tsimane mothers' perceptions of infant health, growth, and development further influence feeding decisions. Results will aid in devising strategies to promote culturally acceptable infant feeding practices that optimally benefit maternal and infant health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Exclusive breastfeeding (EBF) for six months is recommended as optimal for infant health, but is relatively rare worldwide. Early complementary feeding (CF) with foods and liquids other than maternal milk may benefit mothers by reducing the time constraints and energetic costs of nursing, despite any negative consequences for infants. In many populations the primary barriers to prolonged EBF are maternal and social factors that limit breastfeeding frequency or duration—e.g. work outside the home or reliance on bottle- or formula-feeding—with the result that early CF is also often associated with relatively earlier weaning. However, even in populations in which such barriers do not exist, early CF is common. This study investigated patterns of CF among the Tsimane, an indigenous forager-farmer population in Bolivia Amazon. Tsimane infants are breastfed universally and on demand for about two years on average, but introduced CF around four months of age. The aims of the study were to determine what factors in this population predicted earlier CF introduction. It was predicted that early CF, if introduced in order to offset the time and energetic costs of EBF, would be associated with subsequent decreased breastfeeding intensity, poorer infant outcomes, and reduced costs of lactation for mothers—evidenced by earlier resumption of postpartum menstruation, higher urinary C-peptide concentrations, and greater postpartum weight gain.

Both first time mothers (age 17 on average) and high parity mothers (generally 40 years or older, with eight or more births) were more likely to introduce CF earlier. Primiparity and high parity—but not age of CF introduction—subsequently predicted earlier resumption of postpartum menstruation. Different mechanisms appear to mediate these relationships independently of EBF duration. First, high parity mothers had higher BMI following CF introduction, which is consistent with a prediction of the “metabolic load hypothesis”, which states that postpartum menstruation may be triggered by weight gain or stabilization of maternal weight loss. At the same time, perceived low milk supply was also a common reason for reporting very early introduction of CF (often in the first few weeks of life), and was most frequently reported by high parity mothers. This finding suggests a novel relationship between high parity and poor milk production that does not result from low BMI or  biobehavioral factors commonly blamed for low milk supply in Western populations (e.g. scheduled feedings, maternal-infant separation, maternal anxiety about breastfeeding). Future research is needed to determine if and how milk production might be constrained by advanced age or high parity.

Overall, relatively earlier CF introduction (0-3 vs. 4-6 months) was associated with increased CF frequency at later ages, but not with lower frequency of breastfeeding bouts, decreased time spent breastfeeding, or earlier weaning—even if CF was introduced because of low milk. Together, these results suggest that early CF among the Tsimane does not offset breastfeeding intensity, and has little impact on the overall pace of weaning. Similarly for mothers, shorter EBF durations were not associated with subsequent increases in urinary C-peptide concentrations or BMI—further indication that early CF did not reduce mothers lactational costs. Finally, while CF infants aged 0-5 months were relatively smaller than their EBF counterparts, from 6-35 months of age infants introduced CF at 0-3 were larger than infants introduced CF at 4-6 months. Early CF was also not associated with greater likelihood of reported illness before or after six months of age. Therefore, early CF does not appear to have any long term negative effects on infant health or growth in this population.
